channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-12148] Remove TimeRangeTracker as point of contention when many threads writing a Store
item.summary: Remove TimeRangeTracker as point of contention when many threads writing a Store

status.description: A patch for this issue has been uploaded to JIRA by a contributor.

comments.comment: Here is a screen shot of my loading with patched trunk. Patch was from the parent issue. It made for an improvement over what we had previously but even still updating timestamp shines as slow.
TimeRangeTracker no longer shows under same loading with attached patch (coming).

Removes public void includeTimestamp(final byte[] key) { as per Anoop Sam John in the parent issue.

Also addresses the issue Anoop Sam John raises in previous issue with previous patch for TRT (Adds test to prove no longer an issue).

Does Matteo Bertozzi suggested test outside of sync block first.

In simulated test this is much faster.

In loading test, TRT no longer shows as point of contention over ten minute sampling period.

http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12672446/12148.txt

FAILURE: Integrated in HBase-0.98-on-Hadoop-1.1 #544 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/HBase-0.98-on-Hadoop-1.1/544/)
HBASE-12148 Remove TimeRangeTracker as point of contention when many threads writing a Store (apurtell: rev 9f2e748f0a33a5b939a3768c8aeb10432ad43b23)

  • hbase-server/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/hbase/regionserver/TimeRangeTracker.java

SUCCESS: Integrated in HBase-0.98 #573 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/HBase-0.98/573/)
HBASE-12148 Remove TimeRangeTracker as point of contention when many threads writing a Store (apurtell: rev 9f2e748f0a33a5b939a3768c8aeb10432ad43b23)

  • hbase-server/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/hbase/regionserver/TimeRangeTracker.java

Is this correct:


+  long minimumTimestamp = INITIAL_MINIMUM_TIMESTAMP;

...

+    if (timestamp < this.minimumTimestamp) {

+      synchronized (this) {

+        if (!init(timestamp)) {

...

+    } else if (timestamp > this.maximumTimestamp) {

+      synchronized (this) {

+        if (!init(timestamp)) {

...

?

this.minimumTimestamp might be in flight of being changed.

Your reasoning is that minimumTimestamp will only get smaller and maximumTimestamp only bigger... Hence the check here will not actually miss a change? (i.e. if the new value is not smaller than the current minTS it is definitely not smaller than any new version of minTS...?)

That might work, but it's risky. On 32bit systems an update to long is not atomic in Java, so a reader here might see a partially updated long.

I think you cannot get around declaring minimumTimestamp and maximumTimestamp volatile, that will add some of the overhead back in.

stack, Andrew Purtell.

On 32bit systems an update to long is not atomic in Java, so a reader here might see a partially updated long.

I almost feel we should doc this and move on, if anyone is running the server side on a 32 bit JVM they shouldn't. But yeah the potential for torn reads isn't good.

I think you cannot get around declaring minimumTimestamp and maximumTimestamp volatile, that will add some of the overhead back in.

We can make that change

I almost feel we should doc this and move on, if anyone is running the server side on a 32 bit JVM they shouldn't. But yeah the potential for torn reads isn't good.

+1. As well, IIRC, there are other parts of code where we rely on atomic op for 64 bits stuff (as we don't test on 32 bits, what I said is likely true with the usual pattern "not tested means not working").

Your reasoning is that minimumTimestamp will only get smaller and maximumTimestamp only bigger...

Yes.

I think you cannot get around declaring minimumTimestamp and maximumTimestamp volatile, that will add some of the overhead back in.

Let me just add it back if any question at all around correctness (reading, JVM does not have to atomic access on 64bit though in practice seems to work). I did not test in context but using atomic long its about 10-15% slower to complete. Hopefully this not enough to make it a hotspot. Can't check just now.
Addendum that makes min and max atomic longs
Addendum lgtm

isn't the addendum slower? you still have the synchronized and also have the atomic...
can you describe a bit more why you decided to go with it?
why not remove the synchronized if you want to use the atomic?
Fair enough. Let's leave as is or revert.

Did atomic/volatile because of above pushback that no guarantee that long update is atomic – which would mess up any compare. You thinking I've almost put back the synchronized block since the reads are of volatiles/AtomicLong Matteo Bertozzi? The sync scope is narrowed some at least. I didn't measure in context. If any question at all, I'll just put back old behavior until I get chance to test in context again.

Yeah, we should either do AtomicLongs or synchronized + volatile. I was suggesting synchronized + volatile.
AtomicLong vs synchronized+volatile is interesting, we should test. AtomicLong (without synchronized) is probably faster (CAS + volatile), especially when uncontended. In either case we'll eat at least a memory barrier.

I would not trust code that compares anything between multiple threads that is not at least volatile. Not sure of the memory model guarantees even timeline consistency between cores without any for of memory barrier (synchronized, volatile, or Atomic*)
I can do some tight loop testing tonight or tomorrow.

Lars Hofhansl I'll do it boss. I'll do it in context. I have tight loop test already (on tail of TestTimeRangeTracker). My thinking now is to just undo any tie between min and max and let them run free. At read time do the ensuring they have been initialized properly. I'll be back.
Reopened. Looks like consensus is an addendum is needed. I'm going to sink the 0.98.7RC0 since it has only the original change and one other reason.

Reopened. Looks like consensus is an addendum is needed. I'm going to sink the 0.98.7RC0 since it has only the original change and one other reason.

Arggghhh! Was supposed to be small perf improvement. Became a monster. Sorry about that Andrew Purtell

Sorry about that Andrew Purtell

No need to apologize I had an itchy trigger finger on that cherry pick

SUCCESS: Integrated in HBase-0.98 #584 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/HBase-0.98/584/)
Revert "HBASE-12148 Remove TimeRangeTracker as point of contention when many threads writing a Store" (apurtell: rev 00d3eec5d69a8ac735a23fc09be7b8a13c85c0cb)

  • hbase-server/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/hbase/regionserver/TimeRangeTracker.java

FAILURE: Integrated in HBase-0.98-on-Hadoop-1.1 #554 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/HBase-0.98-on-Hadoop-1.1/554/)
Revert "HBASE-12148 Remove TimeRangeTracker as point of contention when many threads writing a Store" (apurtell: rev 00d3eec5d69a8ac735a23fc09be7b8a13c85c0cb)

  • hbase-server/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/hbase/regionserver/TimeRangeTracker.java

I'm going to sink the 0.98.7RC0 since it has only the original change and one other reason.

Arrghh... Sorry Andrew Purtell.

New patch.

Remove synchronize in TimeRangeTracker and use AtomicLongs instead.
Use the AtomicUtil updateMin and updateMax doing updating.
Behavior changes slightly in that min and max are no longer tied
by synchronization so better performance.

Will be back later with data on running this patch in context.... to ensure it removes TRT as point of contention.

Here's another thought? Why does TimerangeTracker need to be synchronized at all?
It's only used in StoreFile.writer. Are we ever appending to the same StoreFile from multiple threads? And if so, maybe that's the place to synchronize - after all in a StoreFile we need to guarantee the order of KVs, so writing threads would need to coordinate anyway.

Can we simply remove the synchronization?

Can we simply remove the synchronization?

Multiple threads can write the memstore at the one time. Memstore is not synchronized. As part of the add to memstore, we update the tracker.

Ditto at read time.

What you reckon? Lars Hofhansl

Hmmm... You are right. I used Eclipse to trace the references, somehow they did not show up, only the ones in StoreFile.Writer. Never mind.

I suppose one observation is that snaphotTimerangeTracker would not need to be synchronized at all, but that would not save us much.

Moving out of 0.98.9.

So how should we move forward with this?
I owe a profiling session that proves it no longer an issue.
Moved out to 0.98.12
Adding a non-blocking TimeRangeTracker that takes advantage of an AtomicReference for concurrency.
HBase-12148.txt added for your consideration.
Patch Submittted for consideration...

Is this actually contended? If not, the issue is due to the memory barriers taken, which CAS does as much as an actual lock.
If this is contended, this should help a lot. Need to perf test.
Oops. I kept the synchronization in the call methods. I will fix and submit another patch.
Adding another patch that removes the synchronization on the get calls.

I can get this intermittently (1 out of 5) but I am still struggling a bit... It is the TestDistributedLogSplitting class that seems to show a race condition... Digging in some more...
deferring from 1.1.2.

Attaching another version (HBASE-12148-V3.patch) of the patch John Leach had been working on, which removes synchronization from TimeRangeTracker. Our own internal testing indicated there was lots of contention.
Patch file is for 'branch-1.3'

Do we see actual contention, as in threads waiting for each other? Or is this slow down due to memory barrier implied by a synchronized (and lock, and CAS, and volatile, and AtomicXXX, etc)?

stack, Walter Koetke, where does this show as a problem? It is at the time when write a store file? Or is it at the time when we insert into the memstore?
Here are the blocked CPU cycles via JProfiler...

I see. So this is at read time from a StoreFile. Is that the main problem? Not contention at write time.

Is the problem that readers lock each other out? That we can solve with a simple ReadWrite lock. (but that still takes a memory fence)

Or we can have two TimeRangeTracker implementations. One that mutable (and synchronized) for the memstore, and one that is immutable (and not synchronized at all) for StoreFiles.

-1 overall

Yes, readers lock each other out when significant load is applied.

If this read load you're applying? Or mixed read-write load?

If the problem is actual contention (threads lock each other out and get suspended) then we should be able to help with read/write locks or mutable/immutable tracker as I suggest above.
So what do we do here?!

Lars, can you be more specific about what the problem is with having just this one implementation, as opposed to one that's synchronized and one that is not? Unless there is a mistake in this patched TimeRangeTracker as implemented, the intent is that it would be thread safe and support both usages, with the AtomicReference, the compareAndSet, etc.

+1 on this last patch. I like the AtomicReference trick. Nice.

I ran into this issue again while profiling. The TimeRangeTracker is reported as the location where we contend most in a ycsb workloadc randomread test doing about 300k ops a second.

Attached are flight recorder before and after where TimeRangeTracker goes from being most contended item to not showing at all.

Let me reattach patch and get a clean build then will apply everywhere.
Try and get a clean run.
We do the patch that Walter Koetke/John Leach attached. It does a nice collapse of the problem synchronizing two independent longs replacing it with a atomic reference.

Lars Hofhansl Speak up if you have a problem w/ my going ahead and committing this. Agree that two different implementations would have been the way to go until the lads showed up w/ this nice 'trick'.... will do for both read/write (it does for sure in the problematic highly-contended read test).

I still don't get what the problem is. There could be two issues:

  1. We have actual thread contention, i.e. threads sleeping, waiting on other threads.
  2. There is no contention, but the memory barriers caused by synchronized (or AtomicXXX or volatile) cause too much of a slow down.

And does this happen upon read or write? We've had issues with this during writes as indicated in the title of this jira, but now this seems to be about reads (by what John Leach says).

With this patch we're creating a new object each time we need to set update the TS, on that write side (compaction, etc) that could kill us.
Seems reply above. I think there is some more discussion to have. We potentially create a lot of object during write (if we're unlucky).

-1 overall

Thanks Lars Hofhansl for the reminder.

Yes, original report was write time.

We don't actually do what the original report was complaining of originally where we are updating TR in MemStore but yeah, I see at flush time we could be doing lots of new instance creations... almost one per Cell as we write them out. Probably fine given they are short-lived objects. We could do your suggestion of two implementations.... The attached one for read time where many threads contending and then another for the case where one thread only writing. Let me look.

v4 fixes one bug in v3 and does some simplification and shutdown of access.

+ We do the assign and declaration in one step so can mark timeRange final.
+ Removed init. It is not used (v3 had interesting issue where passed in param was 'l' – i.e. lowercase L – but internally we were doing a set with '1', the number one.
+ Made the TimeRangeTimestamp inner class all final and private so for sure immutable.

Let me come back w/ a write-time version that does not do object creations.

+1 overall

Ok. So, scratching this last patch. It could make lots of objects at read-time and besides, as Lars Hofhansl says, this issue is about write time, not read time, which is what I (and Walter Koetke) are complaining about.

The fix for read time is pretty straight-forward; just use a TimeRange as opposed to a TimeRangeTracker when reading. See HBASE-15650 for patch.

I'll come back here when doing more write tests; I like the Walter Koetke patch.. maybe we can do a version for write-time (Chatting w/ our Matteo, he was suggesting we might be able to reuse the little data structure objects that are in the Walter Koetke patch which would be great... )

Patch that just makes min and max atomiclongs and just lets them run independent (this has been suggested in this issue variously); undo places where we do tests that tie the two values. No need of this (we'll only update one side or the other).

Running the main in TestTimeRangeTracker, the numbers are erratic. Will run under load to ensure we no longer see this as point of contention.

Another version of the patch that lets min and max run independent of each other using atomiclongs and CAS instead of synchronizes.

Need this because even though doing pure read load at the moment, the memstore uses the includesTimeRange test when its checking Gets to return. Will post image in a sec.
Image of contention found by JFR during intensive random read. Shows how get does timerange check against memstore. Sampler bumps into it a bit.
